Container.Name: MKVCleaver
Container.Overview: MKVCleaver is a tool for batch extraction of data from MKV files [br][br] The GUI of the application is accessed through a modern web browser (no installation or configuration needed on the client side) or via any VNC client. Also, being based on Alpine Linux, size of this container is very small (less than 100MB in download size). [br][br][span][/span] For a complete documentation of this container, see [a href="https://github.com/jlesage/docker-mkvcleaver/blob/master/README.md"] https://github.com/jlesage/docker-mkvcleaver/blob/master/README.md[/a].

Container.Changes:
[font size=4][center]MKVCleaver Change Log[/center][/font] [font size=3][b]v1.3.0[/b][/font] (2019-04-26) - Upgraded MKVToolNix to version 33.1.0. - Now using baseimage v3.5.2, which brings the following changes: - Updated installed packages to get latest security fixes. - Fixed issue where the container could have a zombie process. - Fixed issue where the password would not be submitted when pressing the enter key in the password modal. - Use relative path for favicon ressources to be more friendly with reverse proxy senarios.
[font size=3][b]v1.2.0[/b][/font] (2018-09-18) - Upgraded MKVCleaver to version 0.8.0.0. - Now using baseimage v3.5.1, which is based on Alpine Linux 3.8 and brings the following changes: - Updated installed packages to get latest security fixes.
[font size=3][b]v1.1.3[/b][/font] (2018-03-02) - Now using baseimage v3.3.4, which brings the following changes (since last used version): - Make sure the log monitor is started after the X server. - Fixed an issue where the log monitor `yad` target would use XDG folders of the application. - Fixed issue where log monitor states were not cleared during container startup.
[font size=3][b]v1.1.2[/b][/font] (2018-02-03) - Now using baseimage v3.3.2, which brings the following changes: - Restored timezone support in Alpine Linux images with glibc. - Fixed issue in `add-pkg` helper where a package could be incorrectly detected as installed.
[font size=3][b]v1.1.1[/b][/font] (2018-01-30) - Now using baseimage v3.3.1, which brings the following changes: - Adjusted the way some ressources are accessed to better support reverse proxy to the container.
[font size=3][b]v1.1.0[/b][/font] (2018-01-22) - Now using baseimage v3.3.0, which brings the following changes (since last used version): - For Alpine Linux images with glibc, automatically update dynamic linker's cache after new libraries are installed. - Fixed the LANG environment variable not being set properly. - Added the ability to automatically install a CJK (Chinese/Japanese/Korean) font.
[font size=3][b]v1.0.2[/b][/font] (2018-01-11) - Now using baseimage v3.2.2, which brings the following changes (since last used version): - Upgraded S6 overlay to version 1.21.2.2. - Upgraded glibc to version 2.26 (Alpine Linux glibc images). - Adjusted the way ownership of /config is taken to better support cases where the folder is mapped to a network share. - Small adjustment to the way ownership of files are taken.
[font size=3][b]v1.0.1[/b][/font] (2017-12-12) - Now using baseimage v3.1.4, which brings the following changes: - Set 2 worker processes for nginx.
[font size=3][b]v1.0.0[/b][/font] (2017-11-27) - Initial release.

Config.Name: Config Directory
Config.Description: This is where the application stores its configuration, log and any files needing persistency.<br>Container path: /config

Config.Name: Storage
Config.Description: This location contains files from your host that need to be accessible by the application.<br>Container path: /storage

Config.Name: User ID
Config.Description: ID of the user the application runs as.

Config.Name: Group ID
Config.Description: ID of the group the application runs as.

Config.Name: Umask
Config.Description: Mask that controls how file permissions are set for newly created files. The value of the mask is in octal notation.

Config.Name: Niceness (priority)
Config.Description: Priority at which the application should run. A niceness value of -20 is the highest priority and 19 is the lowest priority.<br><b>NOTE:</b> Setting a negative value requires additional permissions. Thus, <i><b>--cap-add=SYS_NICE</b></i> must be added in <i>Extra Parameters</i> (shown when <i>Advanced View</i> is enabled).

Config.Name: Display Width
Config.Description: Width (in pixels) of the application's window.

Config.Name: Display Height
Config.Description: Height (in pixels) of the application's window.

Config.Name: Secure Connection
Config.Description: Whether or not an encrypted connection should be used to access the application's GUI. Set to <i><b>1</b></i> to encrypt the connection.<br><span style='color: red;'><b>Note:</b></span> When enabling the secure connection, security parameters needs to be generated. This <b>one-time</b> operation is done during container startup. Depending on your system, this could take a few minutes. GUI of the application won't be available until the operation completes.

Config.Name: Extra x11vnc Options
Config.Description: Extra options to pass to the x11vnc server running in the Docker container.<br><span style='color: red;'><b>Warning:</b></span> For advanced users. Do not use unless you know what you are doing.

Config.Name: WEB Port for GUI
Config.Description: Port used to access the application's GUI via the web interface.

Config.Name: VNC Port for GUI
Config.Description: Port used to access the application's GUI via the VNC protocol. Optional if no VNC client is used.
